source.9a4d8acb:
import rasterio
from rasterio.plot import show
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# GeoTIFF image of the Maximum Temperature of January 2010
img_Jan_2010 = rasterio.open('../input/highresolution-geotiff-images-of-climatic-data/wc2.1_2.5m_tmax_2010-01.tif')
plt.figure(figsize=(15,10))
show(img_Jan_2010)

img_August_2012 = rasterio.open('../input/highresolution-geotiff-images-of-climatic-data/wc2.1_2.5m_tmax_2012-08.tif')
plt.figure(figsize=(15,10))
show(img_August_2012)

# image resolution
print(img.height, img.width)

# number of bands
print(img.count)
source.e32923e8:
with rasterio.open("../input/highresolution-geotiff-images-of-climatic-data/wc2.1_2.5m_tmax_2010-01.tif") as img:
    window = Window(0, 0, 100000, 100000)
    data = img.read(window=window, masked=True)

    # adjust these
    value_min = 0
    value_max = 255
    plt.figure(figsize=(15,10))
    show(data, transform=img.window_transform(window), vmin=value_min, vmax=value_max)
source.39ef5595: ### **This Notebook is about a quick look at some GeoTIFF images from My dataset, which I recently added called :** [High-resolution GeoTIFF images of climatic data](https://www.kaggle.com/abireltaief/highresolution-geotiff-images-of-climatic-data)
